people asking wether its the final version cus the files are dated 7/14/2009 and not 10/22/2009. it was available for retail on 10/22/2009 and win7 was signed off as finished and RTM (release to manufacture) on 7/14/2009.
basically its the final version, its not going to be dated 10/22/2009 cus it was finished before that date. the os was finished in july so then they had to burn it to disk, create the packaging and do all the shit to get it produced and into retailers hands for october. millions of copies had to be done worldwide in only 3months, its not an overnight process where they finished the os on 10/21/2009 then created millions of copies by magic so you could buy it on 10/22/2009. after july 14th no changes were made to win7, any changes after release are in the form of update, hotfix and service packs.
its the build number that counts, not the date on the files. use regedit in windows and check the build and you'll see its retail build number.

To Anirudh345:  You probably have a bad burn, for example I burned a WIN7 DVD last summer with build 7600 and it still works perfectly today, another DVD burned a few months ago comes up with install errors (file can't be read) so I threw it out and burned a new DVD from the ISO.  The brand of DVD disk can be a problem with some DVD drives, I use Imation disks in my Samsung SuperWriteMaster drive for best results but other brands/DVD drives combo's may work for you.
To Xtra1979:  I use Nero 8 and it works great for me.  Any program that can burn ISOs and other image formats should work too.  Just don't do any multitasking while the recording is running to avoid errors.  Yes, I know all DVD burners support overrun/underrun protection and will resume burning automatically but I still don't want that happening so I always wait till the burn is done.
